jeopardy_round: WHAT A BUNCH OF TV CHARACTERS

(1, 1).clue: 2nd century B.C. historian Ssu-Ma Ch'ien put together the first comprehensive history of this country

(2, 1).clue: He "hated Christmas! The whole Christmas season...Please don't ask why, no one quite knows the reason"

(3, 1).clue: It's the world's tallest animal whose young is known as a calf

(5, 1).clue: On Sept. 12, 1953 Boston Archbishop Richard Cushing conducted the marriage between this famous pair

(6, 1).clue: The White House was once officially called this "Mansion"

(1, 2).clue: Christian Lange edited "Diplomatarium Norvegicum", a valuable source on this, his native land

(2, 2).clue: "He was doing jumping jacks yesterday", said George W. Bush, downplaying this man's heart problems

(3, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Zoo Atlanta.) The two panda species are the 6- to 12-pound red panda and this 200- to 250-pound species

(5, 2).clue: About his mother's remarriage, Hamlet disdainfully remarks, "Frailty thy name is" this

(6, 2).clue: Named shared by a Leon Uris novel, a Bob Marley album & a book of the Bible

(1, 3).clue: William Prescott's 2 big tales of the Conquistadors were about "The Conquest of Peru" & "The Conquest of" this country

(2, 3).clue: Daffy Duck, a fox from Disney in 1973 & Kevin Costner have all played this role from folklore

(3, 3).clue: Not tabbies or flabbies, but these house cats are known as abys

(5, 3).clue: In the section on marriage in "The Prophet", he wrote "Let there be spaces in your togetherness"

(6, 3).clue: A third mate unlicensed to pilot this ship through Prince William Sound ran it aground

(1, 4).clue: 6th century Roman historian Flavius Cassiodorus did a history of this group that split into Visi- & Ostro- halves

(2, 4).clue: In August of 1971 David Scott dropped a feather & a hammer here; they landed at the same time

(3, 4).clue: Unlike a human, a shark's skeleton is made of this elastic tissue, not bone

(5, 4).clue: The first 2 acts of this 1938 play are titled "The Daily Life" & "Love and Marriage"

(6, 4).clue: This early 20th century German art movement tried to show subjective emotions

(1, 5).clue: This venerable saint's eccesiastical history of England goes up to 731; he died in 735

(2, 5).clue: This chess term for an opening in which pieces are sacrificed has come to mean any ploy or strategem

(3, 5).clue: Hey, Dean!  8 species make up this group of weasel-like mammals including the fisher & sable

(5, 5).clue: He must have liked the family; Thomas Seymour married this English king's widow & later tried to marry his daughter

(6, 5).clue: By tradition, No. 11 Downing Street is the residence of this chancellor

(1, 1).clue: In the next hour, Sir William Walton's concerto for this instrument, featuring Yo-Yo Ma

(2, 1).clue: It's home to over a dozen golden arches of McDonald's & a 630-foot high single stainless steel arch

(3, 1).clue: If this character is coming, have a nice Chianti & some fava beans, though maybe it's best not to invite Ray Liotta

(4, 1).clue: This meat is also called kid & when curried is a Jamaican specialty

(5, 1).clue: Poet Robert who wrote "The Ruling Passion", or prose writer Tom, who kept his "Common Sense"

(1, 2).clue: Now we'll hear a beloved aria by this Italian composer

(2, 2).clue: Located on the Gulf of Finland, it was capital of Russia for 2 centuries

(3, 2).clue: In "Animal House" this actor who played Bluto calls for a "food fight!"

(4, 2).clue: In the film comedy "Love and Death", Napoleon says the Napoleon pastry must be developed before this British meat dish

(5, 2).clue: Nathalia wrote "The Sunken Garden"; Stephen stayed above ground with "The Red Badge of Courage"

(6, 2).clue: If your car breaks down: AAA

(1, 3).clue: Time now for the KJPY clue of the day: born in 1770, he called himself Bacchus, pressing out the wine of musical revelation

(2, 3).clue: This California city was named for the bay, which was named for an Assisi saint

(3, 3).clue: Julia Roberts finds snails are "slippery little suckers" at dinner with Richard Gere and Ralph Bellamy in this film

(4, 3).clue: From a Cree word, this Native American food was made from cranberries, dried deer meat & melted fat

(5, 3).clue: Last name of Edward, who wrote "A Venetian Lover", & of the better-known author of "Firestarter"

(1, 4).clue: Call & win tickets to this "talky" type of voice & piano performance, of songs by Hugo Wolf

(2, 4).clue: Jesse James was terminated in this city, once home to a terminus of the Pony Express

(3, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Leonard Maltin.) At the end of the deli scene, director Rob Reiner's mother has this romantic comedy's funniest line

(4, 4).clue: From the French for "to crunch", it's meat combined with a thick white sauce & deep-fried

(5, 4).clue: The 1874 novel "His Natural Life" by this Aussie author named Marcus was still a good read in 2001

(1, 5).clue: Tomorrow KJPY presents a tribute to this "Fiddler on the Roof" who died in 2001

(2, 5).clue: The stars on its flag seen here stand for hope and liberty, not it and Nevis

(3, 5).clue: Though Wallace Shawn worked with "The Giant" wrestler elsewhere, this '81 food film was not about the big man

(4, 5).clue: These "meats", including the kidneys, heart & brain, must be "the spice of life"

(5, 5).clue: Travel writer Robert; he could have had Childe Harold take a pilgrimage on his "Road to Oxiana"

(0, 0).clue: He's the only athlete in history to play in both the Super Bowl & the World Series
